content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy R{R}.

The reason for choosing this strategy is that if I play R consistently, there's a higher expected value in the long run compared to playing B consistently. Here's the reasoning:

- If my opponent plays R consistently (strategy B{B}), I will earn 45$ per round for 75 rounds (a total of 3375$) while they get 20$ per round (a total of 1500$). So, in this case, I come out ahead by 1875$.
- If my opponent plays B consistently (strategy R{R}), then on the rounds where I play R, I lose 40$ while they get 45$. However, on the rounds where I play B, I earn 20$, and they only get 0$. So, in this case, over 75 rounds, I would come out ahead by 187.5$.
- Since we don't know if my opponent will choose R or B consistently, playing R gives me a higher expected value (3375$ vs 1875$). Therefore, I choose strategy R{R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since I played R in the previous round and my opponent played B, I will switch my strategy for the next round to playing B (strategy B{B}).

In this case, if my opponent plays R again, they will earn 45$ while I get 20$. But since I'm assuming that my opponent is also trying to maximize their payoff, there's a chance they might switch their strategy too. So, playing B could potentially lead me to earn more in the future rounds.

However, if we continue playing this way for multiple rounds, we can see that there will be cycles of R-B-R-B, etc., where neither player gains an advantage over the other in the long run. This is known as a Nash equilibrium. In practice, players may not follow a strict R-B-R-B pattern, but they will try to maximize their payoff based on what they perceive about their opponent's strategy.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

Since I played B in the previous round, and my opponent also played B, I will stick with strategy B{B} for the next round.

In this case, if both of us continue playing B, we will each earn 20$ per round for 75 rounds (a total of 1500$ each). This is lower than what could have been earned by playing R consistently (3375$ per player), but it's still a guaranteed payoff.

If I believe that my opponent is trying to maximize their payoff, they might also continue playing B, as it guarantees them a steady income of 20$ per round. However, if I suspect that my opponent may switch their strategy in the future rounds to try to gain an advantage, I should monitor their behavior closely and adapt my own strategy accordingly.

Regardless of what happens, by playing B consistently, we have reached a Nash equilibrium where neither player can improve their payoff unilaterally by changing their strategy. This means that as long as both players stick with their chosen strategies, the outcome will be the same (each player earning 20$ per round).
